A MoS2-based label-free ultrasensitive electrochemical biosensor for detection of DNA was developed by Wang et al.[220] The basic idea behind development of this biosensor was (a) high electrochemical activity of the ultrasonically exfoliated thin-layer MoS2 nanosheets and (b) differential affinity of MoS2 nanosheets toward single-stranded DNA and double-stranded DNA (dsDNA). The thin-layer MoS2 nanosheets were deposited on the surface of a bare carbon paste electrode (CPE) followed by immobilization of single-stranded DNA molecules. This sensing platform was then used to electrochemically detect a target complimentary DNA sequence in the concentration range of 1.0 × 10−16 to 1.0 × 10−10 m with a detection limit of 1.9 × 10−17 m, with high specificity and sensitivity (Figure 13). The researchers further extended the sensing application of the developed biosensor and demonstrated simultaneous detection of adenine and guanine.
Optical Biosensing: Optical biosensing includes usage of fluorescent or luminescent materials for detecting various biomolecules and enzymes. MoS2 nanosheets have been found to demon strate a high fluorescence quenching making them potential candidates for optical sensing. Combined with this property, the ability of MoS2 nanosheets to show different affinity toward ssDNA and dsDNA have led to the development of fluorescence quenching based optical biosensors for the rapid detection and screening of DNA sequences. Zhu et al. reported the development of single-layer MoS2 nanoprobes for detection of DNA and other biomolecules and demonstrated
that in the absence of a target DNA sequence, the fluorescence intensity of the fluorophore tagged reporter DNA was significantly quenched by the MoS2 nanosheets.[221] However, in the presence of the target DNA sequence, the fluorescence was restored and an increase in signal was observed with increase in target DNA concentration, thereby showing the weak interaction of MoS2 nanosheets with dsDNA as compared to ssDNA. Using the similar sensing technique, a novel monolayered MoS2-based microfluidic biosensor was reported for ultrasensitive DNA detection.[222] Highly concentrated chemically exfoliated thin layered MoS2 nanosheets mixed with ssDNA and dsDNA molecules in zig-zag shaped microchannels demonstrated rapid real-time detection and screening of DNA within minutes (Figure 14a–c).
Aptamer-functionalized MoS2-based optical biosensors have also been developed for biomolecule detection. Kong et al. developed an aptamer-functionalized MoS2 biosensor for detecting prostate specific antigen (PSA).[223] A rigid aptamer structure, induced by strong aptamer–PSA binding, made the weak Van der Waals forces of interaction even weaker and resulted in the release of the aptamer probe from MoS2 nanosheets with simultaneous fluorescence recovery. The biosensor also showed satisfactory results when applied to detection of PSA in human serum samples.
A MoS2-based sensor to detect the activity of DNA methyltransferase enzyme was developed by Deng et al., where MoS2 nanosheets were prepared by ethanol-water-assisted sonication process.[224] The nanosheets were employed as energy acceptors in fluorescence quenching for the detection of DNA methyltransferase where a dsDNA containing DNA adenosine methyltransferase (Dam) recognition sequence and ssDNA was anchored with the substrate DNA onto MoS2 nanosheets by Van der Waals interaction. When the substrate DNA was absorbed on the MoS2 nanosheets, fluorescence of the dsDNA got quenched, whereas when it got methylated by Dam, the fluorescence got restored (Figure 14d,e).
FET-Based Biosensing: A FET-based sensor is generally an insulated gate field-effect transistor in which the ion-conducting liquid solution replaces an electron-conducting solid gate electrode. There is no physical gate in a FET-based biosensor and some specific receptors are used for selective capture of desired biomolecules. The mechanism involved is protonation/deprotonation of hydroxyl group on gate dielectric. It demonstrated high pH sensitivity of 713 for a pH change by 1 unit over a vast range of pH (3–9).

sections.heading: 5. Conclusion and Outlook
sections.text:
In this review, we provide a systematic and detailed overview on the progress of MoS2-based nanomaterials and nanocomposites in the field of nanomedicine in a categorical manner. The different synthesis strategies that have been developed so far for the production of MoS2-based nanomaterials of diverse morphologies have also been reviewed and discussed. The emergence of 2D MoS2 nanomaterials as a novel nanomedicine alternative to graphene and its derivatives in the field of biomedical research can be attributed to the unique structural, optical, electrical, thermal, and biocompatible properties of these nanomaterials. The presence of large surface-area-to-volume ratio and diverse surface chemistry for easy functionalization of this material have helped in achieving high therapeutic and diagnostic cargo loading efficiency and have also facilitated the synthesis of novel multifunctional nanotheranostic platforms, through covalent and noncovalent interactions with biocompatible polymers and targeting moieties.
Depending on the mode of synthesis, structural features, and physicochemical properties, the different morphologies of MoS2 nanostructures developed so far have been explored for different biomedical applications. Among the diverse set of morphologies developed, nanosheets and nanoflakes synthesized through chemical exfoliation and hydro-solvothermal methods have emerged as the most widely used MoS2 nanostructures for applications in drug/gene delivery, phototherapies, and theranostics. This wide applicability of MoS2 nanosheets and nanoflakes achieved in the field of biomedical applications of TMDs can be attributed to the presence of high surface-area-to-volume ratio suitable for therapeutic cargo loading, easy surface functionalization with polymers, and the excellent NIR-responsive photothermal transducing properties which have made these nanosheets ideal for photothermal applications. A thorough analysis of the diverse biomedical applications of MoS2-based nanostructures revealed that MoS2 has been frequently used as a photothermal agent, either alone or in combination with other therapeutic modalities for photothermally triggered drug/ gene delivery, photothermal ablation of tumors, etc. In addition to this, the inherent X-ray absorbing and photoacoustic properties of MoS2 have also helped in exploring them further as bioimaging contrast agents for developing theranostic platforms. The high electrochemical activity of ultrasonically exfoliated thin-layer MoS2 nanosheets has been exploited for developing electrochemical biosensors. Similarly, quantum dots and nanodots which are known for their interesting intrinsic fluorescence properties, have been specifically explored in the field of bioimaging. In addition to these conventional nanostructures, we have also discussed the synthesis and applications of several other morphologies such as nanoflowers, radar-like, agraic-like, coral-like, etc., that have also contributed toward the development of some novel nanomedicine platforms. Most of these morphologies were found to be modifications or derivatives of nanosheet structures and hence have been mostly explored for NIR-responsive photothermal applications.
Though a significant progress has been made in exploring this 2D material as a nanomedicine candidate, however, majority of that research has been focused at the in vitro level, with very little focus on understanding the actual mechanism
of interaction of this class of 2D material with the cells and tissues of the living system. As a result, knowledge related to the toxicity, immunomodulation, pharmacodynamics, and pharmacokinetics profile of MoS2-based nanomaterials is still not very clear and hence requires thorough investigation in small as well as large animal models to understand in depth the processes, mechanisms, and outcomes of the interactions of these nanomaterials once they are inside a living host. In addition to this, emphasis should also be given on the development of better synthesis and surface functionalization strategies that can provide a good control on regulating the size distribution of the synthesized nanomaterials, as previous studies with other 2D materials like graphene have already shown that toxicity of nanomaterials is greatly influenced by their size and surface chemistry, with larger size having more toxicity and higher chances of getting phagocytosed and cleared of the circulation by phagocytic cells. However, for achieving a successful clinical translation of MoS2 as a nanomedicine, dedicated collaborative efforts from different disciplines of science and engineering is needed.
